text: Chapter 2 1 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... Chapter 2 Fundatmental chemistry Atom The smallest unit of an element that has all the properties of that element. The structure of an atom consists of a central nucleus surrounded by electrons. Nucleus The nucleus of an atom usually contains protons and neutrons. The number of protons and neutrons an atom has varies from element to element (we will discuss this later). Proton: positively charged Neutron: not charged Electron: negatively charged Since neutrons are not charged, the number of neutrons an atom has does not affect the overall charge of an atom. However, the number of protons and electrons an atom has does affect the overall charge of an atom. Atoms are neutral This means that the number of protons an atom possesses must equal the number of electrons found surrounding the nucleus of that atom. Ex: A carbon atom has 6 protons in its nucleus, this means a carbon atom must also have 6 electrons surrounding its nucleus. Proton (+6) Electron (-6) Total: (0) Periodic Table Below is the periodic table. It contains all the known elements. As more elements are discovered, they are added to this table. The periodic table is organized based on increasing atomic number and it provides much valuable information about each element. The noble gases (He, Ne, Ar, etc) are the elements in the far right column of the table. These elements are very stable on their own and they conduct electricity. We will learn about the importance of stability a little bit later in this chapter. Atomic number The atomic number is the number of protons found in the nucleus of an atom. Atomic weight (mass) Atomic weight is the mass of an atom. This value is basically the number of protons and neutrons found in the nucleus of that atom. 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 2 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... Calculation example The atomic mass for He (helium) is 4.003. This is an average value. For this class, we will follow the general rule for rounding or dropping to make the numbers easier to work with. If we do that to the atomic mass value 4.003, it becomes 4. Atomic mass equation Atomic mass = proton + neutron Question: How do we figure out the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons helium has? *(Make sure you know how to do this.) P (proton) = 2 (because atomic number is the same as proton number) E (electron) = 2 (because atoms are neutral. Each atom has equal number of protons to electrons) N (neutron) = 2 (use the atomic mass equation) Isotope Isotopes are like siblings from the same family. What do I mean by that? Siblings are related to each other through their parents but different as individuals. Look at the following atomic diagrams. See if you can figure out how these 3 atoms are similar (related) and how they are different from each other. Hydrogen: This is the first element on the periodic table. Based on the

periodic table, hydrogen should have 1 proton, 1 electron, and no neutrons (because the atomic mass is 1. (1= 1+ neutron). Therefore, neutron equals 0. Deuterium: This is an isotope of hydrogen. Note the number of protons is the same as hydrogen (hence, it is part of the family) but the nucleus of deuterium has 1 neutron. Therefore, the atomic mass for deuterium is 2, not 1. Tritium: Another isotope of hydrogen. The difference is the number of neutrons again. This time, the nucleus contains 2 neutrons. The atomic mass for tritium is 3. Comparing these 3 isotopes, the only difference between them is the number of neutrons. Radioisotope : Some isotopes are unstable. The nucleus of an unstable isotope will decay (break apart). When this happens, it is known as a radioisotope. Different radioisotopes takes different amounts of time to break down. The amount of time for a radioisotope to reduce by half (amount) is known as the half- life. Ex: Carbon 14 (C-14) has a half-life of 5,730 years. This means every 5,730 years the amount of C-14 will reduce by half. Because of its long half-life, it is good for dating fossils. Isotope notation Isotopes are written with their atomic mass and symbol together. There are several ways to notate an isotope. Take carbon isotopes for example: 12C, C-12 both mean the same thing. The number 12 represents the atomic mass of this carbon isotope. C is the symbol for carbon. Since all carbons have 6 protons, a 12C or C-12 isotope has 6 protons, atomic mass of 12 and 6 neutrons. You can determine the number of neutrons by subtracting the atomic mass and the atomic number. Lecture video (Atom and isotope) Watch the lecture video as it reiterates the information and provides explanations of the lesson. Worksheet 2.1 Practice answering these questions to check for understanding (Not for grade but great for test preparation). Downloadable pdf Electrons We talked about electrons earlier. Electrons are negatively charged. They occupy space surrounding the nucleus of an atom. The number of electrons an atom has equals the number of protons the atom has (Remember, atoms are neutral in charge.) Just to show you some shapes of orbitals. It is not important that you memorize the names or shapes of different orbitals for this class. However, you need to understand that orbitals are found in electron shells and that different electron shell can hold different number of electrons. 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 3 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... Here is some terminology to know about electrons: Orbital : Volume of space occupied by electrons Electron shell : where electrons are organized surrounding the nucleus. Each electron shell can hold a certain number of electrons. For this class, you need to remember that the first level can hold a maximum of 2 electrons (called 1s), the second level can hold a maximum of 8 electrons (2S and 2P), the third level can hold a maximum of 18 electrons (3S, 3P, 3d), and

the fourth level can also hold a maximum of 18 electrons (4S, 4P, 4d). Order of the electron orbitals Electrons of an element are distributed in the orbitals of electron shells. When there are multiple electrons, the interactions between the electrons cause the electron shell to establish different orbitals where each has a different energy level. S orbital has the lowest energy, follows by P orbital. To describe how the electrons are organized into the various orbitals according to their energy level, we use anelectron configuration to demonstrate that. When I need to write out an electron configuration, I find using the periodic table helpful for determining the order of the orbital fill and electrons shells. The horizontal row of the periodic table is called a period. Starting from the top, each period provides clue for the order of the orbital energy within each electron shell. Compare the periodic table (on the left) to the electron shell and orbital energy order (on the right). The order of the electron energy level according to electron orbital follows the order of the periodic table order. Watch the lecture video below for further discussions using examples. 1. 1st electron shell comprised of only 1S orbital and it can hold maximum of 2 electrons. 2. 2nd electron shell comprised of 2S, follows by 2P orbital. Electrons are organized first into S orbital, then into P orbital if necessary. 3. 3rd electron shell comprised of 3S, follows by 3P. Again, S is filled before P is filled. But 3d cannot be filled until 4S is filled. 4. 4th electron shell comprised of 4S, follows by "3d", then 4P. This is because the 3d orbital has greater energy than 4S but less energy than 4P. Valence shell and valence electrons Valence shell: the most outer electron shell of an atom. Valence electrons: electrons that are found on the most outer electron shell. For example: Electron configuration for P (phosphorus): P has an atomic number of 15. That means there are 15 protons (+) and 15 electrons (-). The electron configuration for P is: 1S2, 2S2, 2P6, 3S2, 3P3 (Total of 15) The valence shell for P would be shell 3 (colored in yellow). The valence electron number would be 5 because there are 2 electrons in the 3S orbital and 3 electrons in the 3P orbital. Lecture video (Electron configurations) Watch the lecture video as it reiterates the information and provides explanations of the lesson. Determine the electron configuration for Sulfur (sulfur has 16 electrons): The order of electron configuration is: 1S2, 2S2, 2P6, 3S2, 3P4 (Total of 16) If you still have questions about the above materials, you need to reach out to me (by attending student 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 4 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... support hours in-person or online or email me) or attend tutoring at the tutoring center/ session offered by Valencia college. Do not wait! Worksheet 2.2 Practice answering these questions to check for understanding (Not for grade but great for test

preparation). Downloadable pdf Atoms are neutral but most are not stable Now that we have talked about atoms, we are going to talk about how atoms come together to form molecules. Molecules are made when 2 or more atoms bind together creating a stable chemical structure. The chemical structure gives the molecule specific properties. Why are most atoms unstable? Atoms are unstable if their outermost electron shell (valence shell) is not filled to the maximum. Remember that the last slide mentions some magic numbers you will need for this class. The first level can hold a maximum of 2 electrons. The second level can hold a maximum of 8 electrons (2, 6). The third level can hold a maximum of 18 electrons. (2, 8, 8). If an atom has electrons hanging out in an outer electron shell that is not filled to the maximum, the atom is not stable. What happens to atoms that are not stable? To obtain stability, they will look to their neighbors (surrounding atoms) for help to become stable. So what does an unstable atom do to become stable? Octet Rule Atoms follow the octet rule to become stable. Octet rules: Atoms tend to share, lose, or gain 1 or more electrons to achieve a filled outer electron shell. The atoms involved in such activity are bound together as stable molecules. What does that mean? Every hydrogen atom has 1 proton and 1 electron. The single electron makes hydrogen atoms unstable because its lowest electron shell is not filled to the maximum. To become stable, it needs to have 2 electrons, in the electron shell. What do they do about that? Well, the octet rule says they can either share, lose, or gain electrons to achieve a filled outer electron shell. So they do! Hydrogen atoms near each other will share their electrons with each other. Shared electrons are counted for both atoms. To satisfy the octet rule, they each contribute an electron. Together they share a pair of electrons between them. Since they share these electrons, they are able to count these electrons as their own. So you can say that both hydrogen atoms now have 2 electrons in their outermost electron shell. When atoms share electrons between them, they are chemically bound together. This chemical bond is known as the "covalent bond". Each covalent bond forms when a pair (2) of electrons are shared between 2 atoms. In chemistry, a covalent bond is depicted as a solid line between the atoms that share electrons. It is possible for 2 atoms to share more than 1 pair of electrons between them. HONC rule Ok, this rule I made up myself but it is easy to remember. Hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon are four most common elements in biomolecules. The HONC rule should help you remember how these four elements generally behave in attempt to satisfy octate rule. H O N C 1 2 3 4 (pronounced "honk". This is the "HONC" rule) What is the

HONC rule? HONC are 4 most common elements found in living systems. H for hydrogen, O for oxygen, N for nitrogen, and C for carbon. They each want to make a certain number of covalent bonds (because they want to become stable.) Hydrogen will make 1 covalent bond. Oxygen will generally make 2 covalent bonds. Nitrogen will make 3 covalent bonds. Carbon will make 4 covalent bonds. Remember this and you will find my HONC rule makes it easy to determine the number of covalent bond these atoms will likely form. Example: Hypochlorous acid (HOCl) : What should be your thought process? 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 5 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... It can be drawn as: The solid lines indicate sharing of a pair of electrons between the atoms. These bonds are known as covalent bonds. Covalent bonds are strong bonds when compared to other intermolecular forces. Stronger the bond, the greater the energy required to break it. The electron "dots" in the hypochlorous acid molecular structure are the valence electrons. Valence electrons are electrons on the outer electron shell of the atom. The 4 valence electrons around the oxygen and the 6 valence electrons around the chlorine are paired up with each other. Reading molecular formula Before we go any further, you need to know how to read a molecular formula. Molecular formulae are written with the element symbols (if you do not recognize one, you should pull out your periodic table). Then the formula gives you information about how many of each elemental atoms are found in the molecule. The picture below shows the molecular formula of water. How do you read that? Hydrogen symbol is H and oxygen symbol is O. The subscript that follows the symbol tells you how many of that particular atoms are in this molecule. Therefore, H2O(water) is made with 2 hydrogen atoms and 1 oxygen atom. There are total of 3 atoms in a water molecule. Try this! How about the glucose molecule? The formula for glucose is C6H12O6. How many carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen atoms are there in 1 glucose molecule? How many atoms are there in a glucose molecule? Answer: Glucose (C6H12O6) has 6 carbon, 12 hydrogen, and 6 oxygen atoms. There are total of 24 atoms in a glucose molecule. Lecture video (Molecular Formula) Watch the lecture video as it reiterates the information and provides explanations of the lesson. Covalent bonding forms molecules A covalent bond is a chemical bond formed between 2 nonmetal atoms as they share 1 or more outer electrons with each other to satisfy the octet rule (become stable). How do you know which elements are metal or nonmetal? Look at the periodic table. 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 6 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... Example: Carbon has 6 electrons, with 2 electrons filling the 1st electron shell (1S2) and 4 electrons in the outer electron shell (2S 2 and 2p 2). It wants to have 4 more electrons to fill its outer electron shell (the second electron shell

can hold a maximum of 8 electrons because the S orbital can hold 2 and the P orbital can hold 6 electrons total). Each hydrogen has only 1 electron in its "only" electron shell (which wants total of 2 electrons). They each need to find 1 more electron to become stable. Carbon shares 1 electron with each hydrogen. Between carbon and each hydrogen, they share a pair of electrons between them. Therefore, 1 covalent bond is formed between carbon and each surrounding hydrogen. Can you have more than one covalent bond between atoms? Yes, it is possible to share more than once with the same atom. Here are a few examples. See if you can figure out why they are stable. Remember to follow the octet rule. 1. CO2 (carbon dioxide gas) 2. N2 (nitrogen gas) 3. H2CO2 (formic acid) What elements do not need help to become stable? Answer: Noble gases (think about why that is!) Chemical bonds and interactions Atoms come together to form molecules by sharing electrons to form covalent bonds. However, molecules interact with each as well. The interactions between molecules are driven by molecular property. The chart shows the types of bonds and interactions occur between atoms and molecules. The greater the bond energy, the greater the force needed to separate the bond or the interaction. It also means the amount of energy released when the bond or the interaction is broken is proportional to the bond energy. 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 7 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... As you probably notice the bond energy within covalent bond varies considerably. The amount of bonding energy between two covalently linked atoms has to do with the number of electrons bonded and the distance of the bond. For example, O=O has greater bond energy than O-O. The double bonded oxygen atoms shared 4 electrons while the single bonded oxygen atoms shared 2 electrons. The bond energy between O=O is around 119 Kcal/mol while O-O is only about 34 Kcal/mol. What a big difference! What should you know from the chart? You should know that covalent bond is a very strong bond. All other bonds and interactions are weak by comparison. Individual ionic bond is very weak but ions form lattice so the collective energy is very high if you add up all the individual ionic bonds. You will learn more about ionic bond, hydrogen bond, and hydrophobic interaction in later pages. Lecture video Watch the lecture video as it reiterates the information and provides explanations of the lesson. Representing molecule There are many way to represent a molecule. You can write the molecular formula or you can draw the structure of the molecule, known as the structural formula. In the molecular formula, you only write down the symbols of the elements and the ratio of those elements in the molecule. When you are asked to draw a molecule, show your molecule in the structural formula shows how the atoms are connected to each other. Some of the molecular structures

you will see in the lesson will be the skeletal formulas. In the skeletal drawing, carbon atoms are assumed to be at the ends and the corners of joining bonds. Hydrogen atoms are also omitted. It is assumed the appropriate number of hydrogen atoms will be attached to each carbon in the molecule to make 4 covalent bonds for each carbon atom. Besides carbon and hydrogen atoms, everything else must be written out. Do you have questions? No questions are too small. Get help from me or from Valencia college tutoring. Do not wait! Worksheet 2.3 Practice answering these questions to check for understanding (Not for grade but great for test preparation). Dowloadable pdf Electronegativity 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 8 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... Sharing ≠ 50/50 What does that mean? Remember that covalent bonds are formed between 2 atoms sharing a pair of electrons between them. If the 2 atoms are the same kind, they will share electrons equally between them (50/50). If the pair of electrons are shared by atoms of different kinds, they do not usually share these electrons equally. This is caused by the difference in nuclear attraction for electrons between the 2 elements. Electronegativity table: As you move up the periodic table, the electronegativity value increases. As you move to the right of the periodic table, the electronegativity value increase. This means excluding the noble gases column, fluorine is the highest and the furthest right of the table so it has the highest electronegativity value (4). (Memorize this) What do you need ot know for the test? 1. Remember the general trends for electronegativity value in relation to their positions in the periodic table. (Values increase as the element is higher up in the periodic table, values increase from left to right.) 2. The periodic table positions for (H, Li, Na, Mg, K, Ca, C, N, O, F, P, S, and Cl). If you remember these commonly seen elements in biochemistry their positions in the periodic table, you can predict if a polar or nonpolar bond will form between these elements). 3. Fluorine has the highest electronegativity value (4.0). It will form polar bond with all other elements. 4. You don't need to memorize the table or the values. If the value is needed for a question on the test, the information will be provided. 5. Do the practice problems in the worksheet when you get to the end of the section. Polarity Nonpolar covalent bonds are formed between atoms of the same element or the difference in electronegativity value between the elements is 0 or very low. The nuclear attraction (electronegativity) for the shared electrons are the same. Polar covalent bonds are formed between atoms of different elements or the difference in electronegativity value between the elements is high. The nuclear attraction (electronegativity) for the shared electrons are different. *If the electronegativity difference (means subtraction of the two values) is low (less than 0.5), we will consider these nonpolar bond. If the electronegativity difference is

greater than 0.5 but less than 1.8, it is polar bond. If the difference is greater than 1.8, it is most likely that an ionic bond will form between them. Meaning that electrons will be transferred. (See later slides on ionic bonds.) Study guide 1. You do not need to memorize the electronegativity values for the test. If you need an electronegativity table to help you figure out the relationship between 2 elements, it will be provided. 2. You do need to know the general trends in electronegativity values on the periodic table. 3. You do need to know that F (fluorine) has the highest electronegativity value. 4. You do need to know whether a covalent bond is going to be polar or nonpolar by the general locations of where the elements are on the periodic table. 5. To determine polarity, you find the "difference" between the two atoms. If the difference is below 0.5, it is considered as nonpolar. Difference between 0.5 and 1.8 is considered polar. Difference of 1.8 or greater is likely to be ionic. Lecture video Watch the lecture video as it reiterates the information and provides explanations of the lesson. 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 9 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... Worksheet 2.4 Practice answering these questions to check for understanding (Not for grade but great for test preparation). Downloadable pdf Ionic bond What happens when a metal and a nonmetal with very different electronegativity values are paired up? They become ionized and they form ionic bond. Sodium (Na) and chlorine (Cl) example: The difference in electronegativity indicates one atom has a very strong affinity for electrons while the other atom is rather weak. If they are both unstable (outermost electron shell is not full), they will attempt to become stable by obtaining or giving up electrons. See the information below for sodium (Na) and Chlorine (Cl). Notice their electronegativity values are very different. If you subtract their electronegativity values from each other, the difference is 2.5 . Recall the difference of electronegativity values help predict the type of bonds or interactions likely to take place. If the difference is less than 0.5, you are most likely to observe a nonpolar covalent bond. If the difference is between 0.5 or greater but lower than 1.8, you are likely to observe a polar covalent bond. If the difference is 1.8 or greater, you are likely to observe an ionic bond. You need to remember these 2 values for the exam. To become stable, Na atom needs to get rid of the lonely electron on its outer electron shell (because it is not possible to get 7 electrons by sharing). Chlorine atom needs one more electron, which can be obtained by sharing (forming covalent bond) or by gaining electrons. In this case, Na has an electron that it wants to get rid of and Cl would be happy to accept the electron. Since Na has a very weak nuclear attraction for its electron, it is easy for Na to give

up the single electron on its outer electron shell. Chlorine has a strong nuclear affinity for electrons so it "takes" the electron from Na. This give-and-take relationship results in what is known as an ionic bond between sodium and chlorine. Electron transfer Since sodium (Na) atom has a low electronegativity value and it wants to give up the 1 valence electron, losing one electron means the net charge of the atom is now positive one. Sodium ion has 11 positive protons (number of protons do not change) and 10 negative electrons (due to loss of 1 electron), it is now net positive 1 (+1). Chlorine atom accepts an electron from sodium so it now has 18 electrons (-) and 17 protons (+). The overall charge is now -1. A charged molecule or a charged "atom" is known as an "ion". • Cations are positively charged (+) Ex: Na+ • Anions are negatively charged (-) Ex: ClNow practice determining when ionic bond will form: Polar molecule Polar molecules are made of mostly polar covalent bonds and the distribution of the polar covalent bonds are asymmetrical. Ex: Water molecule (H2O) is a polar molecule because the H-O covalent bond is polar. (See picture below) H atom has an electronegativity value of 2.2 while O atom has an electronegativity value of 3.4. Their difference (3.4-2.2=1.2) is greater than 0.5, which means it is definitely a polar covalent bond. Both H-O covalent bonds in H2O molecule show gathering of shared electrons closer to the oxygen atom. This makes the oxygen atom slightly more negative than the hydrogens. We use the δ (delta) symbol to indicate the uneven distribution of electrons between the atoms. The side of the covalent bond that is more electronegative, we assign the δ- symbol. The other side of the covalent bond that is more electropositive, we assign the δ+ symbol. Since the O-H bond, the oxygen has a stronger electronegativity (means it pulls the shared electrons closer toward it), it gets the δ- symbol. The hydrogen of the O-H bond has a weaker electronegativity (means it does not pull the shared electrons close), it gets the δ+ symbol. Assigning these symbols on the covalent bonds of a molecule can help us visualize whether the distribution of the electrons is even (symmetrical) or uneven (asymmetrical). 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 10 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... The H-O covalent bonds are not symmetrical. The bond angle is about 105˚ from each other due to the presence of 4 valence electrons (lone pairs) repelling each other on the oxygen atom. (see above image) The lone pair valence electrons repulsion push the hydrogen atoms down to form a 104.5˚ angle instead of 180˚ angle. (See image below) Since the shared electrons are closer to oxygen and the uneven distribution of electrons cannot be cancelled by the structure of the molecule. This is a polar molecule. Examples of polar vs. nonpolar molecules • Polar molecules: Asymmetrical polar covalent bonds made these polar molecules • Nonpolar molecule: Symmetrical

polar covalent bonds. Cancelling effect made them nonpolar molecules Hydrogen bond Hydrogen bonding occurs when the hydrogen atom is attracted to an atom that is more electronegative (high electronegativity value) of another molecule or another part of the same molecule. 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 11 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... Something to know: 1. Hydrogen bonding involves hydrogen atoms. 2. Hydrogen bonding can occur between molecules or within the same molecule. 3. Polar molecules or polar covalent bonds are likely to generate hydrogen bonds between them. 4. Hydrogen bonding is weak in comparison to covalent bonding. 5. Water molecules are polar. They form hydrogen bonds between themselves and with other polar molecules. 6. Large molecules such as DNA form hydrogen bonds within the molecule. Do you have questions? Get help now! You can attend Zoom help sessions, email me, or attend tutoring offered by Valencia college. Water as solvent Solvent A solvent dissolves another substance. Solute A solute is the substance that dissolves in a solution. It is also proportionally the lesser amount in a solution. Solution = Solute + Solvent Ex: Salt water is a solution. It is made with salt (solute) and water (solvent). Why does salt dissolve (disappear) in water? (Study this example) 1. Table salt (NaCl) is held together by charges (see ionic bond slide). As a solid, Na+ and Cl- are attracted to each other so they are hold together as Na+Cl-. 2. When NaCl is in water, the polar water molecules surround Na+ by pointing the electronegative oxygen at the Na+ and pointing the positively charged hydrogen at the Cl-. 3. Once the Na+ and Cl- are separated from each other, it is "dissolved" and cannot be seen in water. Hydrophobic vs. hydrophilic What is hydrophobic? Hydro= water Phobic= fearing of What is hydrophilic? Philic = loving Look at the two molecules below. what do they have in common? 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 12 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... If you say "they both are made of carbon and hydrogen atoms" then you are correct! What is the big deal about that? Read on! Hydrophobic interaction is the interaction between nonpolar molecules in an aqueous environment. The nonpolar molecules in the environment will aggregate (interact) and repel water molecules between them. If a molecule is made of all or mostly hydrogen and carbon, it is known as hydrocarbon molecule. Hydrocarbon molecules are nonpolar. Remember this rule. It will be very useful for you. The molecular picture above shows two examples of hydrocarbon molecules (which means they are both nonpolar molecules). Hydrophilic is the property of a polar molecule dissolving in water. Since water molecules are polar, other polar molecules will interact with water and disassociate in water. The result is the compound "dissolves/disappears" in the water. Important to remember: 1. Polar molecules interact with polar molecules. They are hydrophilic in nature. 2. Nonpolar molecules interact with nonpolar molecules. 3. Hydrocarbon molecules or hydrocarbon parts are nonpolar. They are hydrophobic in nature. Lecture video Watch the lecture video as

it reiterates the information and provides explanations of the lesson. Worksheet 2.5 Practice answering these questions to check for understanding (Not for grade but great for test preparation). Downloadable pdf Chemical reaction When do you have a chemical reaction? A chemical reaction takes place when you have transformation of one set of molecules to another. That measn if you start with the molecule NaCl but after the reaction it becomes NaF. You have a chemical reaction. If there is no molecule change then no chemical reaction occurred. Chemical reactions are often written as equations. Molecules needed to produce the products are known as the reactants. The arrow indicates the direction of the reaction. The molecules generated by the reaction are known as products. The total number of atoms for each element must be the same between the reactant side and the product side because no matter is created or destroyed during the chemical reaction. That is known as "balanced". Decoding the chemical equation The number in front of the chemical formula is known as the coefficient. It shows the number of the particular molecule are involved in this chemical reaction. If there is only 1 of this molecule involved in the reaction, by default, the equation will not put a coefficient in front of the formula. 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 13 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... Both sides have 4 hydrogen atoms and 2 oxygen atoms. The equation is balanced. Watch the lecture video below on how to balance a chemical equation. Then, use the worksheet on the next page to practice "balancing equations". You will definitely be tested on how to balance chemical equations. Worksheet 2.6 Practice answering these questions to check for understanding (Not for grade but great for test preparation). Downloadable pdf Do you still have questions? Get help now! You can attend Zoom help sessions, email me, or attend tutoring offered by Valencia college. Water is essential to life on earth Why are water molecules so important to life on earth? This has a lot to do with the chemical properties of water molecules. One very important reason has to do with water molecules being polar. This allows water molecules to interact with other polar molecules and form hydrogen bonds. Here are some interesting things you need to know about water molecules: 1. Water molecules can be found in solid (ice), liquid (aqueous), and gas (vapor) phases. 2. Water molecules are cohesive (sticky) because they are polar which means they form hydrogen bonds. Remember, polar molecules interact with other polar molecules. 3. Water has high surface tension. The surface tension (force) is the attractions between the molecules on the surface of the liquid. The high surface tension in water is due to the fact that water molecules are polar (attracted to each other) and they form hydrogen bonds with each other but less attracted to other molecules in the surrounding area (such as air molecules). See the picture of water bug walking on water. 4. As a polar

molecule, water is an important biological solvent. pH (Potential of Hydrogen) When water (solvent) dissolves substances (solute) and the resulting solution shows hydrogen ions were released, this is called an acid or acidic solution. pH measures the concentration of hydrogen ions (H+) in a solution. The greater the H+ concentration, the lower the pH. As defined in the text: Acid: Solutions that release protons (H+). Proton is the same as hydrogen ion. In this class we will remember it as a proton. When you see H+ in the product side, it indicates that a proton is released so HCl is an acid. Strong acid: Disassociate 100% into anion and proton (H+). Base: Solutions that accept protons (H+). Also, the presence of hydroxide ion in the product side means the substance is a base. A solution that produces OH- will neutralize the H+. That means NaOH is a base. When you see OH- on the product side, that means you have a base. Strong base: Disassociate 100% into cation and hydroxide (OH-). Water is an acid and a base 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 14 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... Two water molecules hydrogen bonded to each other. Hydronium (H3O+) is formed when H2O Hydroxide (OH-) is the base in the binds to a proton (H+). equation. When you see hydroxide (OH ) on the product side, you know Therefore, H3O+ is the equivalent of a there is base in the equation. proton. This is the acid in the equation. As you can see, the above equation shows an acid (H+) and a base (OH-) on the product side, this should give you a clue that water is both an acid and a base. One part acid and one part base neutralizes each other, resulting in water (which is neutral in pH). pH value How we end up with the pH values? Since solutions can be acidic or basic, we can measure the acidity of a solution by measuring its proton concentration. Water has a proton concentration of 0.0000001. That is the same as 10-7. This value is pretty difficult to work with so we will use a mathematic calculation known as the common logarithm to convert the proton concentration. The common logarithm calculates the exponent of the base of 10. A log is the inverse of an exponent. Following example shows the log base of 10. The answer "2" is the exponent. So if pure water has a concentration of 0.0000001 which is the same as 10-7, you can say that the log10 (0.0000001) is -7. But wait, a negative value is too confusing to work with. We will put a negative sign in the pH conversion equation so we will always end up with a positive pH value. So here it the pH value equation: pH value = -log10 (proton concentration) pH scale The right of the pH scale shows the proton concentration. The left side of the pH scale the pH values are given and these values are based on the

-log10(proton concentration) calculation. Familiarize yourself with the pH scale. You need to know: 1. Lower proton concentration means higher pH value, making the solution more basic. 2. Higher proton concentration means lower pH value and the solution is more acidic. 3. To change pH of a solution you will need to manipulate the proton concentration. 4. The 2 extreme ends of the pH scale represent stronger acids and bases. 5. To change the pH of a solution from lower pH value (more acidic) to a higher pH value (more basic or less acidic), you will need to add a higher pH solution to the acidic solution to 3/4/25, 17:14 Chapter 2 15 of 15 https://softchalkcloud.com/lesson/ﬁles/aUqWtRgikl4Sw... make the acidic solution less acidic. Buffer in the living system Buffer : Weak acid and/or weak base solution that resists big pH changes even when large amounts of acids or bases are added. It is often made by pairing a weak acid or weak base with its conjugated acid or base. Buffers are important in biological systems. They help maintain homeostasis of pH in a living system. For example, human blood has a pH of 7.35 to 7.45 and it is maintained by the carbonic acid (H2CO3) and bicarbonate ion (HCO3 -) system. The carbonic acid absorbs excess base while the bicarbonate ion absorbs excess acid entering the system. Every buffer has its buffering range and buffering capacity. If a buffer is challenged with excessive addition of acid or base, it will eventually give up and the pH of the environment will suddenly increase or decrease.
